description: The ancient city of Swenett in Egypt, called Syene by the Greeks.

names.details: Taḥrīr-i Ṣūret-i Iḳlīm el-Me’ḫūẕe Min Ṣuveri’l-eḳālīm ma‘a Baḥrü’l-Fārs Der-tafṣīl-i Ḥudūd-i Vilāyet-i Mıṣr u Cifār el-Menḳūle Min Teḳāvīmi’l-emṣār: ... The land of Egpyt is located on the east of Arabian Peninsula. Its southern frontier reaches the bilād-ı Sūdān (lands of the Sudan), that is Nūbe (Nubia?) and the other non-tribes of dark faces, from whose direction the Nīl-i Mıṣr (Nile River) comes. And its northern boundary is the Baḥr-i Rūm (Mediterranean Sea), and from Refaḥ (Rafah) to ‘Arīş (‘Arish), Cifār, Ṭīne (Tine/Al-Tina), Dimyāṭ (Damietta), the coast of Reşīd (Rosetta/Rashid), and İskenderiyye (Alexandria); and passing between Alexandria it reaches Berḳa (Barqa/Cyrenaica). Its western boundary runs between Berḳa (Barqa) and İskenderiyye (Alexandria) to the Cenevīz sāḥili (Genoese coast) and Ẓahru’l-vāḥāt, joins the frontiers of Nūbe (Nubia?). As for its southern boundary, it extends from the borders of Nubia to the cultivated lands by the Baḥr-i Ḳulzüm (Red Sea), and finally reaches the Tīh-i Benī İsrā’īl. Then turning northward once again, it reaches the Baḥr-i Rūm (Mediterranean) and ends at the place called Refaḥ (Rafah) where we began.... And the eastern border of Egypt extends from Baḥr-i Ḳulzüm (Red Sea) to the vicinity of Usvān (Aswan), and to ‘Ayẕāb (Aidhab), Kuṣayr (Qusayr/Quseir), Kulzüm (Suez), and the Tīh-i Benī İsrā’īl... [partial translation]
